nodes.body:
Thanks for the thorough reviews!

Since there have been some changes to `pdf.IsUniform`, I was able to remove some unnecessary lemmas. And I think the naming and styling is in line with the guide.
There was a new PR which changed uniform distribution a bit. Can you merge master and see if it still compiles?

> There was a new PR which changed uniform distribution a bit. Can you merge master and see if it still compiles?

Indeed some of my rewrites that made use of the old definition (`Measure.map B ‚Ñô = (Œº s)‚Åª¬π ‚Ä¢ Œº.restrict s`) have broken.
Ok, looks like it wasn't hard to fix. Updated

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11562~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.
bors d+

:v: enricozb can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8795653663/job/24137090001)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8795653663/job/24137090471)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8795653663/job/24137090617)
A super minor comment. A longer review should maybe be done by someone with a bit more familiarity with integration/measure theory in mathlib.
maintainer merge
LGTM, thanks! Just some very minor style nits; feel free to merge after addressing the ones you agree with.
A super minor comment. A longer review should maybe be done by someone with a bit more familiarity with integration/measure theory in mathlib.
Thanks for this! A few stylistic comments below. Maybe we could also add some more documentation about how the proof works, next to each of the main lemmas?
I don't know enough about probability to be confident in my review, but it mostly looks good to me. You might want to merge master into this branch to make sure nothing broke since you made the PR
maintainer merge
LGTM, thanks! Just some very minor style nits; feel free to merge after addressing the ones you agree with.
This notation already exists in mathlib, and becomes available once you `open Real`.
Oh good point. I'll wait for some more comments before pushing to the branch again just so I don't have to wait for checks to rerun yet again

This is the sort of thing that `refine'` is really good for. Does something like this work? (untested)
`refine' stronglyMeasurable_iff_measurable_separable.mpr ‚ü®N'_measurable l, {0, 1}, _‚ü©`
`refine'` was a good suggestion, I've simplified some portions of the proof where appropriate
Can you give this a more descriptive name? Maybe something like needleCrosses
Can you use lowerCamelCase for terms of types (See [here](scoped[MeasureTheory]))
This link doesn't work for me
My bad, this is the link: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/wiki/Lean-4-survival-guide-for-Lean-3-users#naming-conventions
So I've read through this, do you have any recommendations on handling random variables (since they are typically just upper cased)? Should I just stick to the style guideline?
In this case I would stick with the guidelines. OTOH if the random variable is a local variable within a theorem or a definition, then you can name it as you'd like (typically X)

```suggestion
need to consider only a single vertical line positioned at `x = 0`. A needle therefore crosses the
```

```suggestion
    (hs : MeasurableSet s) (hf : ‚àÄ·µê x : Œ±, x ‚àà s ‚Üí 0 ‚â§ f x) :
```

You could perhaps move this into mathlib itself, though maybe it's too specialized... I'm not sure. In any case,
```suggestion
lemma set_integral_toReal_ofReal_nonneg_ae {Œ± : Type*} [MeasureSpace Œ±] {s : Set Œ±} {f : Œ± ‚Üí ‚Ñù}
```

While there wasn't much of a discussion, I [mentioned it on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Buffon's.20Needle.20general.20lemmas/near/419465574), and sort of agreed that it was a bit too specific.

```suggestion
  The line is at `x = 0`, and the needle crosses the line if its projection
```

This seems to rely on the exact normal form that `ring_nf` produces. Does this work (untested)?
```suggestion
  simp_rw [MeasureTheory.Measure.volume_eq_prod, MeasureTheory.Measure.prod_prod, Real.volume_Icc,
    ENNReal.ofReal_mul hd.le]
  ring_nf
```
nice eye.
Can `continuity` or `fun_prop` do this?
Neither `continuity` or `fun_prop` were able to resolve these.

```suggestion
lemma N'_stronglyMeasurable : MeasureTheory.StronglyMeasurable (N' l) := by
```

```suggestion
      rw [neg_div, and_comm, ‚Üê tsub_le_iff_right, zero_sub]
```
We use the spelling `a ‚â§ b` in general (since all lemmas are writing in this form and it is harder to use whenever we need syntactic equality). Can you change to this convention here and below?
Should I do the same for strict inequality eg `0 < d`?
Yes
Although, if you have an assumption of the form 0 < a, then it should be instead phrased as a \neq 0
Not sure I understand, `a` is a real number here.
I mean to say that the spelling of `d \neq 0` is preferred over `0 < d` if it is an assumption while `0 < d` is preferred over `d \neq 0` if it is the conclusion.
I think I'm confused. Those aren't equivalent statements in the reals. So I can't substitute `0 < d` for `d \neq 0` in an assumption, because I also need it to be non-negative.
Oh, I'm sorry. I was under the impression that we are talking about `nnreal` rather than `real`. In this case what you have is correct.
It seems to me that you only need `0 \le d` (for this and the subsequent lemmas). Can you check if you can replace `hd` by a nonnegative assumption? Similarly for the `hl` assumption
Ok, I see that you need positivity for line 225.

```suggestion
    ‚ü®needleCrossesIndicator_measurable l, {0, 1}, ?separable‚ü©
```
Relying on the particular form that `ring_nf` uses is somewhat brittle. Can you take a look if you can avoid that?
Should there be a lemma about this?
`MeasureTheory.Measure.volume_eq_prod`

```suggestion
lemma intervalIntegrable_min_const_sin_mul (a b : ‚Ñù) :
```

Fortunately computers are better at this:
```suggestion
  field_simp
  ring
```
Wow. I wasn't aware of `field_simp`. One question: Usually, when I use `ring`, Lean will ask me instead to replace it with `ring_nf`. Here, it doesn't say that. Do you know why?
`ring` has several subroutines. If the first one doesn't work, it tells you to run `ring_nf`, which is the second subroutine. `_nf` stands for "Horner normal form".
Can you inline this lemma?
I definitely don't like how it's at the top of the file, but it's used both in `buffon_short` and `buffon_long`.
Ok I've inlined it
Can you put everything in a namespace like `BuffonNeedle`?

```suggestion
lemma volume_needleSpace : ‚Ñô (needleSpace d) = ENNReal.ofReal (d * œÄ) := by
```

```suggestion
  decl   : buffon_short buffon_long
```
Should I use `BuffonNeedle.buffon_short` and `BuffonNeedle.buffon_long`, since I'm putting everything under a namespace?
Yes, declaration names in the yaml files need to be fully qualified

Hmm, looks like there are [build errors](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8362867760/job/22894523493?pr=10189). I wonder if `100.yaml` doesn't have visibility into the files imported by `Archive.lean`?
Could you adjust the uses of `.sqrt` to use the new notation?
Done, also merged in master.

These will look nicer in the web docs as
````suggestion
```lean
‚Ñô[N] = (d * œÄ) ‚Åª¬π *
    ‚à´ Œ∏ in 0..œÄ,
      ‚à´ x in Set.Icc (-d / 2) (d / 2) ‚à© Set.Icc (-Œ∏.sin * l / 2) (Œ∏.sin * l / 2), 1
```
````

```suggestion
abbrev needleSpace : Set (‚Ñù √ó ‚Ñù) := Set.Icc (-d / 2) (d / 2) √óÀ¢ Set.Icc 0 œÄ
```
You might find a lot of `refine'`s can be made `refine` with no other changes.
nit: we pretty much never have blank lines within mathlib proofs. Your proofs are very well structured with indentation anyway, so I think removing blank lines will be no great loss.

nit:
```suggestion
  have indicator_eq (x Œ∏ : ‚Ñù) :
      Set.indicator (Set.Icc (x - Œ∏.sin * l / 2) (x + Œ∏.sin * l / 2)) 1 0 =
      Set.indicator (Set.Icc (-Œ∏.sin * l / 2) (Œ∏.sin * l / 2)) (1 : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) x := by
```
to keep this separate from the `simp_rw` below
